item.title: Setup
item.description: Making your own Quartz Setting up Quartz requires a basic understanding of git. If you are unfamiliar, this resource is a great place to start!

item.title: Editing Content in Quartz
item.description: Editing Quartz runs on top of Hugo so all notes are written in Markdown. Folder Structure Here’s a rough overview of what’s what.

item.title: Obsidian Vault Integration
item.description: Setup Obsidian is the preferred way to use Quartz. You can either create a new Obsidian Vault or link one that your already have.

item.title: Preview Changes
item.description: If you’d like to preview what your Quartz site looks like before deploying it to the internet, here’s exactly how to do that!

item.title: Deploying Quartz to the Web
item.description: Hosting on GitHub Pages Quartz is designed to be effortless to deploy. If you forked and cloned Quartz directly from the repository, everything should already be good to go!

Characteristics of living things MRS GREN Movement An action by an organism or part of an organism causing a change of position Respiration The chemical reaction in cells that breakdown nutrient molecules and release energy for metabolism Sensitivity The ability to detect or sense stimuli in the internal or external environment and to make appropriate responses Growth A permanent increasing in size and dry mass by an increase in cell number or cell size or both Reproduction It is the process that make more of the same kind of organism Excretion Removal from organism of the waste products of metabolism (chemical reactions in cells including respiration) toxic materials and substances in excess of requirements Nutrition Taking in of materials for energy, growth and development.
Classification Classification means putting things into groups. The main reason for classification of living things if to make it easier to study them.

Features of Organism All living organism have certain features in common including: Cytoplasm Cell membrane DNA Ribosome The 5 kingdoms [[Prokaryotes]] [[Fungi]] [[Protoctista]] [[Animals]] [[Plants]]
Animals Multicellular Cells have a nucleus, but no cellwall or chloroplast Feed on organic substances made by other living organism Section under [[Classification]], [[Features of Organism]]

Fungus It is made up of thread like “hyphea” They have nuclei inside the cytoplasm They are multicellular or single cell THey dont have chloroplast They help in decomposition They have cell wall (made with “chitin”) !

Plants Multicellular Cells have a nucleus Cells are made up of cellulose and often chloroplasts Feed ny photosynthesis May have roots, stems and leaves Section under [[Classification]], [[Features of Organism]]

Prokaryotes (Bacteria) They are single cell They don’t have nucleus They have cell wall not made of cellulose Some have slime capsule The cytoplasm contain granules of glycogen lipid and other food reserve All bacteria contain a single chromosome They help in decomposition !

Protoctista Multicellular or unicellular Cell have nucleus Cell may or may not have a cell wall and chloroplast Some feed by photosynthesis and others feed on organic substances made by other organisms Section under [[Classification]], [[Features of Organism]]
Topics: 1 2 3 TABLE id as "ID" FROM "200 Physics/010 Topics" SORT id
Acceleration SI Unit = m/s2 Acceleration is a vector quantity It is the rate of change of velocity per unit of time $$A = \frac{V_2 - V_1}{t}$$ Related [[Acceleration of Freefall]] [[Velocity]]
Adding vectors Examples of vectors 1 2 3 4 5 6 ---> OBJECT (pushing a table) 50 N <--- OBJECT (moving ball) 20 m/s Add vectors Adding vectors is just like adding two regular numbers
Drag force Drag force is a resistance (opposite force) given by the air (or) water when the object is moving in it Drag force is also called air resistance Related [[Force]] [[Friction]]

Elastic Material Spring (material) regains its original shape after the removal of weight Plastic Material Plastic material can not regain its original shape after the weight is removed Force extension graph !
Equilibrium Clockwise moment = Anti Clockwise moment ![[Pasted image 20220809220653.png]] ignore the 450N under the boy for this example
Force SI Unit = N Force is a vector quantity It is an influence tending to change the motion of a body or produce motion or stress in a stationary body $$F = m \cdot a$$
Friction Friction is the force between two surfaces which impedes motion and results in heating Friction force act opposite to the motion Friction produces energy loss.
Impulse Impulse = [[Force]] x [[Measurements#Measuring Time |Time]] SI Unit = Ns 1 A force can change motion and direction of an object.
Mass SI Unit = Kg Mass is the quantity of a substance It is a scalar quantity $$m = \frac{weight}{gravity}$$ $$m = \frac{density}{volume}$$ $$m = \frac{force}{acceleration}$$

Measuring length Unit of length is ‘meter (m)’ Measuring Techniques Using measuring tape Using ruler Using [[Vernier Caliper]] ^c586f1 Using micrometer Measuring the length of the thread Keep the wire near to the ruler Keep the wire straight End of the wire start at ZERO !
Moment (or) Turning effect Moment = [[Force]] x Distance SI Unit = Nm $$M = F \cdot D$$ ![[Pasted image 20220809215944.

Momentum Momentum (p)= [[Mass]] x [[Velocity]] SI Unit = Kg m/s Only moving objects have momentum If an object is not moving it’s in rest therefore its momentum will be 0 Example Find the momentum of a ball rolling with the velocity of 20¬†m/s and mass of 0.

Pressure (1st Method) SI Unit = N/m3 (or) Pascal (Pa) Pressure can be measure by ‘manometer’ Manometer is a small U-shaped tube holding small amount of liquid $$P = œÅ \cdot g\cdot h$$ $$œÅ = \frac{M}{V}$$

Quantities Scaler Quantities which has only magnitude (size) Vector Quantities which has both magnitude and direction Overview Quantity SI Unit Other Unit Scaler Vector [[Measurements#Measuring length]] m mm, cm, km true Temperature kelvin (k) ¬∞C, ¬∞F true [[Acceleration]] m/s2 true [[Speed]] m/s km/h true [[Velocity]] m/s true [[Mass]] kg g, mg true E.
Speed SI Unit = m/s Speed is a scalar quantity It is the a distance travelled by an object in a given time Formulae Speed $$S = \frac{d}{t}$$ Average speed $$A.
Springs Extension (‚àÜX) SI Unit = m Increase in length of spring after it is loaded by [[Mass]] !
Improve stability Lower the CoM 1 Increase the base Related [[Moment]] [[Force]] [[Equilibrium]] Centre Of Mass: A point representing the mean position of the matter in a body or system.
Velocity SI Unit = m/s Velocity is a vector quantity It is the displacement of an object in a certain direction $$V = \frac{\text{displacement} (d)}{\text{time(t)}}$$

Weight SI Unit = N Weight is the force exerted on the mass of a body by a gravitational field It is a vector quantity $$W = F = m \cdot g$$ Gravity acts on the object towards the center of the earth Related [[Different gravitational fields]] [[Force]] [[Quantities]]
Acceleration of Freefall Speed increase Acceleration constant (9.8m/s2) Distance travelled increases
Barometer Used to measure atmospheric pressure ![[Pasted image 20220523222624.png]] Air applies pressure on mercury The level of mercury raises in the tube
Different gravitational fields Not all planets have the same gravitational strengths Gravity Body 9.
Oscillation Repeated back and forth movements on either side of any equilibrium position ^cbdf28 How to calculate average value Lets take a sample of 5 oscillations, [1.
Vernier Caliper ![[Pasted image 20220516142704.png]] Used to measure small lengths Used to improve accuracy Least measurable length = 0.

Measuring Volume Of Irregular Objects Instruments Measuring cylinder Water Procedure Fill the water in the measuring cylinder Take initial volume (reading) Put object into measuring cylinder Group A B C Initial (V‚ÇÅ) 31cm¬≥ 29cm¬≥ 30cm¬≥ Final (V‚ÇÇ) 36cm¬≥ 35cm¬≥ 35cm¬≥ Group A $$V = V_2 - V_1 $$ $$V = 36 - 31$$ $$V = 6cm^3$$

Measuring Density Of Irregular Objects Instruments Measuring cylinder Water Electronic balance Procedure Keep the measuring cylinder with water on the electronic balance Mark its mass (M1) and volume (V1) Put the object inside the measuring cylinder and measure its final mass (M2) and final volume (V2) Density can be found using the formulae below $$D = \frac{M_2 - M_1}{V_2 - V_1}$$

Finding Time Taken For 1 Oscillation Instruments String Stand Bob (metal ball) Stop watch Context n = Number of oscillations (usually 10) t = Time taken for n oscillations T = Time taken for 1 oscillation $$ T = \frac{t}{n} $$

item.title: Callouts
item.description: Callout support Quartz supports the same Admonition-callout syntax as Obsidian. This includes 12 Distinct callout types (each with several aliases) Collapsable callouts See documentation on supported types and syntax here.

item.title: Configuration
item.description: Configuration Quartz is designed to be extremely configurable. You can find the bulk of the configuration scattered throughout the repository depending on how in-depth you’d like to get.

item.title: Custom Domain
item.description: Registrar This step is only applicable if you are using a custom domain! If you are using a <YOUR-USERNAME>.github.io domain, you can skip this step.

item.title: Ignoring Notes
item.description: Quartz Ignore Edit ignoreFiles in config.toml to include paths you’d like to exclude from being rendered. 1 2 3 4 5 6 .

item.title: Quartz Philosophy
item.description: ‚Äú[One] who works with the door open gets all kinds of interruptions, but [they] also occasionally gets clues as to what the world is and what might be important.

item.title: Search
item.description: Quartz supports two modes of searching through content. Full-text Full-text search is the default in Quartz. It produces results that exactly match the search query.

item.title: Showcase
item.description: Want to see what Quartz can do? Here are some cool community gardens :) Quartz Documentation (this site!) Jacky Zhao’s Garden Scaling Synthesis - A hypertext research notebook AWAGMI Intern Notes Shihyu’s PKM Chloe’s Garden SlRvb’s Site Course notes for Information Technology Advanced Theory Brandon Boswell’s Garden Siyang’s Courtyard Data Dictionary üß† sspaeti.

item.title: Troubleshooting and FAQ
item.description: Still having trouble? Here are a list of common questions and problems people encounter when installing Quartz. While you’re here, join our Discord :)

item.title: Updating
item.description: Haven’t updated Quartz in a while and want all the cool new optimizations? On Unix/Mac systems you can run the following command for a one-line update!
